name: James Baldwin
summary: Novelist, playwright, and activist who explored the intricacies of racial, sexual, and class distinctions.
detail: Baldwin's essays, such as Notes of a Native Son, explored the unspoken complexities of racial, sexual, and class distinctions. He was a vital voice during the Civil Rights Movement, offering a critique of both white racism and black despair.

name: The Haitian Revolution
summary: The only successful slave revolt in history that led to the founding of a free Black state.
detail: This revolution shook the world, challenging the beliefs of the era regarding black inferiority. It resulted in the establishment of Haiti, the first independent black republic in the Americas.

name: Black Power Movement
summary: A political and social movement advocating for self-determination for people of African descent.
detail: Emphasized racial pride and the creation of black political and cultural institutions. It challenged the non-violent philosophy of the early Civil Rights Movement.

name: The Wretched of the Earth
summary: Frantz Fanon's analysis of the dehumanizing effects of colonization and the path to liberation.
detail: A psychiatric and psychologic analysis of the dehumanizing effects of colonization. It is considered a handbook for the Black revolution.

name: The Conservation of Races
summary: A speech by W.E.B. Du Bois arguing that race is a socio-historical concept, not just biological.
detail: Du Bois argues that the black race has a specific cultural message to deliver to the world and must maintain its identity to do so.

name: Rastafari Movement
summary: A religious and political movement that developed in Jamaica, regarding Haile Selassie I as a messianic figure.
detail: Combined Protestant Christianity, mysticism, and a Pan-African political consciousness. It views Africa (Zion) as the original birthplace of mankind.

name: Afrocentrism
summary: A cultural ideology focusing on the history of Black Africans and their role in history.
detail: A response to Eurocentric attitudes, it seeks to reclaim African history and place African ideals at the center of any analysis that involves African culture.

name: Nelson Mandela
summary: South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and the first Black head of state of South Africa.
detail: After serving 27 years in prison, Mandela negotiated the end of apartheid and became a global symbol of peace and forgiveness.

name: Toussaint Louverture
summary: The most prominent leader of the Haitian Revolution.
detail: He fought for the Spanish against the French; then for France against Spain and Great Britain; and finally, he fought on behalf of Saint-Domingue.

name: Jean-Jacques Dessalines
summary: A leader of the Haitian Revolution and the first ruler of an independent Haiti.
detail: Dessalines declared Saint-Domingue independent on January 1, 1804, renaming it Haiti.

name: Aimé Césaire
summary: Martinican poet, author, and politician; a founder of the Négritude movement.
detail: His text Discourse on Colonialism is a classic text of anti-colonial literature.

name: Haile Selassie I
summary: Emperor of Ethiopia and a defining figure in modern Ethiopian history and the Rastafari movement.
detail: He led the resistance against the Italian invasion of Ethiopia and was instrumental in the founding of the OAU.

name: Patrice Lumumba
summary: Congolese independence leader and the first Prime Minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
detail: His government was deposed in a coup during the Congo Crisis, leading to his assassination, which turned him into a martyr for the Pan-African cause.

name: Kwame Nkrumah
summary: First President of Ghana and a founding father of Pan-Africanism.
detail: He led the Gold Coast to independence from Britain in 1957. He envisioned a 'United States of Africa'.

name: Malcolm X
summary: Human rights activist and prominent figure in the Nation of Islam.
detail: A courageous advocate for the rights of blacks, a man who indicted white America in the harshest terms for its crimes against black Americans.

name: W.E.B. Du Bois
summary: Sociologist, historian, civil rights activist, and author.
detail: One of the most important thinkers in American history. He co-founded the NAACP and was a leader of the Niagara Movement.

name: Frantz Fanon
summary: West Indian psychiatrist and political philosopher.
detail: His works are influential in the fields of post-colonial studies, critical theory, and Marxism.

name: Thomas Sankara
summary: Burkinabé military officer and socialist revolutionary.
detail: Known as 'Africa's Che Guevara', he renamed the country Burkina Faso ('Land of Incorruptible People') and launched massive social and ecological programs.

name: Steve Biko
summary: South African anti-apartheid activist and founder of the Black Consciousness Movement.
detail: His famous slogan 'Black is Beautiful' challenged the psychological inferiority complex instilled by apartheid.

name: Marcus Garvey
summary: Jamaican political activist and founder of the UNIA.
detail: He advocated for the 'Back to Africa' movement and economic independence for Black people globally.

name: Angela Davis
summary: American political activist, philosopher, academic, and author.
detail: A major figure in the prison abolition movement, she analyzes the intersections of race, gender, and class.

name: Assata Shakur
summary: Former member of the Black Liberation Army and political refugee.
detail: Living in exile in Cuba, her autobiography is a seminal text for modern revolutionaries.

name: Huey P. Newton
summary: Co-founder of the Black Panther Party.
detail: He formulated the Party's ideology of revolutionary intercommunalism and armed self-defense.

name: Stokely Carmichael (Kwame Ture)
summary: Prominent organizer in the Civil Rights Movement and the global Pan-African movement.
detail: He popularized the term 'Black Power' and later moved to Guinea, adopting the name Kwame Ture.

name: Black Skin, White Masks
summary: A sociological study of the psychology of racism and the dehumanization inherent in colonial domination.
detail: Fanon applies psychoanalysis to explain the feelings of dependency and inadequacy that Black people experience in a white world.

name: The Souls of Black Folk
summary: A seminal work in African American literature by W.E.B. Du Bois.
detail: Du Bois famously prophesied that 'the problem of the Twentieth Century is the problem of the color-line'.

name: How Europe Underdeveloped Africa
summary: Walter Rodney's study of the impact of the slave trade and colonialism on the history of Africa.
detail: The book argues that Africa was deliberately exploited and underdeveloped by European colonial regimes.

name: The Mis-Education of the Negro
summary: Carter G. Woodson's critique of the US educational system.
detail: Woodson argues that the school system conditions Black people to accept a subservient role in society.

name: I Write What I Like
summary: A compilation of writings by Steve Biko.
detail: Published posthumously, it contains Biko's most important essays on the psychological liberation of Black people.

name: Women, Race, & Class
summary: Angela Davis's analysis of gender, race, and class in the US.
detail: A fundamental text for intersectional feminism, tracing the history of the women's suffrage movement and its relationship with abolitionism.

name: The Black Jacobins
summary: C.L.R. James's history of the Haitian Revolution.
detail: James places the Haitian Revolution in the context of the French Revolution, showing the agency of the enslaved in winning their own freedom.

name: The New Jim Crow
summary: Michelle Alexander's argument that mass incarceration is a new form of racial control.
detail: Alexander argues that the US criminal justice system functions as a contemporary system of racial control aimed at African Americans.

name: The Fire Next Time
summary: Two essays by James Baldwin on race and religion.
detail: A powerful warning about the destructive nature of racism and a plea for love and brotherhood to end the racial nightmare.

name: Pan-African Congresses
summary: A series of meetings to address the issues facing Africa as a result of European colonization.
detail: These congresses laid the groundwork for the independence movements in Africa and the global solidarity of African people.

name: Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA)
summary: Black nationalist fraternal organization founded by Marcus Garvey.
detail: Dedicated to racial pride, economic self-sufficiency, and the formation of an independent black nation in Africa.

name: Harlem Renaissance
summary: An intellectual, social, and artistic explosion centered in Harlem, New York.
detail: Known as the 'New Negro Movement', it marked a moment when African American culture was celebrated and redefined.

name: Civil Rights Movement
summary: A campaign to abolish legalized racial segregation and discrimination in the United States.
detail: Through nonviolent protest, the movement achieved landmark legislation including the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

name: Black Panther Party
summary: A revolutionary socialist political organization founded by Bobby Seale and Huey P. Newton.
detail: The party monitored police behavior and instituted community social programs, most famously the Free Breakfast for Children Programs.

name: Anti-Apartheid Movement
summary: A global movement to oppose the system of apartheid in South Africa.
detail: This international movement used boycotts and sanctions to pressure the South African government to dismantle its racist system.

name: Black Consciousness Movement
summary: A grassroots anti-apartheid activist movement in South Africa led by Steve Biko.
detail: Filled the void left by the banning of the ANC, focusing on psychological liberation and black pride.

name: Black Lives Matter
summary: A decentralized political and social movement advocating for non-violent civil disobedience in protest against police brutality.
detail: Founded in response to the acquittal of Trayvon Martin's killer, it has grown into a global movement against anti-Black racism.

name: Soweto Uprising
summary: A series of protests led by Black school children in South Africa.
detail: Students protested the introduction of Afrikaans as the medium of instruction. The police response shocked the world and revitalized the anti-apartheid struggle.

name: Walter Rodney
summary: Guyanese historian, political activist, and scholar.
detail: Rodney was assassinated for his activism. He emphasized the importance of intellectuals connecting with the working class ('grounding').

name: Audre Lorde
summary: Writer, feminist, womanist, librarian, and civil rights activist.
detail: Self-described as 'black, lesbian, mother, warrior, poet', she dedicated her life to addressing the injustices of racism, sexism, classism, and homophobia.

name: Ella Baker
summary: One of the most important African American leaders of the twentieth century and a behind-the-scenes organizer.
detail: She mentored emerging activists like Stokely Carmichael and Rosa Parks, believing that 'strong people don't need strong leaders'.

name: Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC)
summary: One of the major American Civil Rights Movement organizations.
detail: SNCC played a major role in the sit-ins and Freedom Rides, and later evolved toward Black Power under Stokely Carmichael.

name: Maya Angelou
summary: American memoirist, poet, and civil rights activist.
detail: Her memoir I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings brought her international acclaim. She worked with both MLK and Malcolm X.

name: Carter G. Woodson
summary: Historian known as the 'Father of Black History'.
detail: He launched Negro History Week (now Black History Month) to ensure the history of Black people was not erased.

name: Afrofuturism
summary: A cultural aesthetic that combines science-fiction, history, and fantasy to explore the African-American experience.
detail: It reimagines the future through a Black cultural lens, connecting the African diaspora to technology and the cosmos.

name: Afropessimism
summary: A critical framework that describes the ongoing effects of slavery and the nature of Blackness as 'social death'.
detail: It argues that anti-blackness is a foundational element of the world, meaning Black people are positioned outside of humanity.

name: Henri Christophe
summary: A key leader in the Haitian Revolution and the only monarch of the Kingdom of Haiti.
detail: He built the Citadelle Laferrière, one of the largest fortresses in the Americas, to defend the new nation.

name: Jomo Kenyatta
summary: Anti-colonial activist and the first President of Kenya.
detail: He was a principal figure in the transformation of Kenya from a colony to an independent republic.

name: Edward Wilmot Blyden
summary: Educator, writer, and diplomat, widely regarded as the 'father of Pan-Africanism'.
detail: He argued that Africa had a distinct contribution to make to humanity and advocated for the return of the diaspora to Africa.

name: Nnamdi Azikiwe
summary: The first President of Nigeria, known as 'Zik'.
detail: A driving force behind Nigerian independence and a key figure in the Pan-African movement.

name: Julius Nyerere
summary: Anti-colonial activist and first President of Tanzania.
detail: He promoted 'Ujamaa' (familyhood), a socialist philosophy of self-reliance and cooperative economics.

name: Robert Sobukwe
summary: South African political dissident and founder of the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC).
detail: He broke away from the ANC to form the PAC, advocating for an exclusively Africanist approach to liberation.

name: Ahmed Sékou Touré
summary: First President of Guinea.
detail: Famous for saying 'No' to France in 1958, choosing immediate independence over continued association with the colonial power.

name: Amy Jacques Garvey
summary: Journalist, activist, and leader in the UNIA.
detail: She was crucial to the survival of the UNIA after Marcus Garvey's imprisonment, editing the 'Negro World' newspaper.

name: Claudia Jones
summary: Trinidadian-born journalist and activist.
detail: Deported from the US for her communist activities, she founded the West Indian Gazette in London and the precursor to the Notting Hill Carnival.

name: Martin Delany
summary: Abolitionist, journalist, and physician, arguably the first proponent of Black Nationalism.
detail: He famously said, 'We are a nation within a nation', advocating for black emigration to Africa or Latin America.

name: George Padmore
summary: Trinidadian journalist and Pan-Africanist.
detail: A key advisor to Kwame Nkrumah, he helped organize the 1945 Pan-African Congress in Manchester.

name: Léopold Sédar Senghor
summary: Poet, cultural theorist, and the first President of Senegal.
detail: He championed Négritude, a framework for black writers to critique colonialism and celebrate African culture.

name: Amílcar Cabral
summary: Agricultural engineer and leader of the independence movement in Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde.
detail: He emphasized the importance of culture in the liberation struggle, famously telling cadres to 'Tell no lies, claim no easy victories'.

name: C.L.R. James
summary: Trinidadian historian, journalist, and socialist.
detail: His masterpiece The Black Jacobins is the definitive history of the Haitian Revolution.

name: Langston Hughes
summary: Poet, social activist, novelist, playwright, and columnist.
detail: One of the earliest innovators of the then-new literary art form called jazz poetry.

name: Ida B. Wells
summary: Investigative journalist, educator, and early leader in the civil rights movement.
detail: She documented lynching in the United States, showing that it was often used as a way to control or punish Black people who competed with whites.

name: Fela Kuti
summary: Nigerian multi-instrumentalist, bandleader, composer, political activist, and Pan-Africanist.
detail: The pioneer of Afrobeat, he used his music to criticize the corruption of the Nigerian government and colonial mentality.

name: Toni Morrison
summary: Novelist, essayist, editor, and teacher.
detail: The first African American woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. Her work explores the Black American experience.

name: Septima Clark
summary: American educator and civil rights activist.
detail: Known as the 'Grandmother of the Civil Rights Movement', she developed the literacy and citizenship workshops that empowered thousands to vote.

name: Sister Outsider
summary: A collection of essays and speeches by Audre Lorde.
detail: Contains her classic essays like 'The Master's Tools Will Never Dismantle the Master's House'.

name: Born in Blackness
summary: Howard W. French's history of Africa and the making of the modern world.
detail: French retells the history of the modern world, placing Africa at the center of the narrative of global trade and modernity.

name: Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents
summary: Isabel Wilkerson's examination of the unspoken caste system in America.
detail: She links the caste systems of India, Nazi Germany, and the United States to explain how hierarchy is maintained.

name: Black Marxism
summary: Cedric J. Robinson's history of the Black Radical Tradition.
detail: Robinson introduces the concept of 'Racial Capitalism' and critiques traditional Marxism for ignoring the racial nature of capitalism.

name: Establishment of African Union (AU)
summary: The successor to the Organization of African Unity (OAU).
detail: Launched in Durban, South Africa, to accelerate the process of integration in the continent.

name: March on Washington
summary: A massive protest march that occurred in August 1963.
detail: The setting for MLK's 'I Have a Dream' speech, it was a pivotal moment in the passage of the Civil Rights Act.

name: Montgomery Bus Boycott
summary: A seminal event in the Civil Rights Movement.
detail: Sparked by Rosa Parks' arrest, the 381-day boycott resulted in the Supreme Court ruling that segregation on public buses was unconstitutional.

name: Organization of African Unity (OAU)
summary: An intergovernmental organization established to promote the unity and solidarity of African states.
detail: Founded in Addis Ababa, its main goal was to eradicate colonialism and apartheid from the continent.
